section.title: Introduction
section.para: This specification targets designers of XLIFF Extracting and Merging Tools for content owners. XLIFF Roundtrip designers of all kinds will benefit, no matter if they design their XLIFF Extractor/Merger for corporate or blog use.

Extraction and merging behavior is out of the normative scope of OASIS XLIFF Specifications. Although those specifications do provide some guidance for Extractor and Merger Agents, XLIFF TC did not attempt to prescribe how exactly to use XLIFF to represent native content. This is mostly because XLIFF is a native format agnostic Localization interchange Format.

This &releaseinfo; targets designers of XLIFF Extracting and Merging Tools for content owners. XLIFF Roundtrip designers of all kinds will benefit, no matter if they design their XLIFF Extractor/Merger for corporate or blog use.

Extraction and Merging behavior is out of the normative scope of OASIS XLIFF Specifications. Although those specifications do provide some guidance for Extractor and Merger Agents, XLIFF TC did not attempt to prescribe how exactly to use XLIFF to represent native content. This is mostly because XLIFF is a native format agnostic Localization Interchange Format.

This specification gathers common problems that are prone to appear when Extracting XLIFF Documents from HTML, generic XML, or MarkDown. This specification shows why some Extraction approaches will cause issues during an XLIFF Roundtrip, issues often so severe that Merging back of target content will not be possible without costly postprocessing or could fail utterly. This best practice guidance provides better thought through alternatives and shows how to use many of advanced XLIFF features for lossless Localization roundtrip of HTML and XML based content. Most of the times there are no ultimate prescribed solutions, rather possible design goals are described and best methods how to achieve them proposed.

section.title: Inline Codes
section.para:
Recommendations for processing standalone and spanning inline functional and formatting elements of localizable content.
Perform complete extraction
Represent spanning code using <sc /> and <ec /> (or <pc></pc> where possible)
Represent standalone code using <ph>
Include inlines in extracted content
XLIFF2 prose.

section.title: Representing Spanning Codes
section.para: Spanning codes in the original format are created by opening code, content and closing code. In HTML that can be <bold>text</bold>, in RTF \b text \b0.
In XLIFF2 such code can be represented using <sc />/<ec /> pair universally, or by <pc></pc> in case of well formed spanning code.

Ideally the original format is documented enough to instruct Extractor about role of each inline code. For example XML schema allows to declare elements using keyword EMPTY. This way all elements, which are not declared EMPTY, can be represented as described above. To further help the extraction process the following recommendation could be implemented in original XML format: For interoperability, the empty-element tag SHOULD be used, and SHOULD only be used, for elements which are declared EMPTY.[XML].

Following this recommendation an empty would be encoded as and represented as / pair, as compared to always empty
, which would be represented by .
This concept is illustrated by spanning_as_ph.

section.title: Outermost Tag Pairs
section.para: In some cases the inline codes might enclose the localizable string in a way, which would make leaving them out of extracted text a convenient action. For example paragraph containing only a link text, could be extracted as the link text only, without the being represented. This relates to previous bad example with spanning tag represented as two s and leaving the opening one out.

This approach could, however, cause issues in cases where the inline codes needs to be manipulated during the roundtrip (deleted, or their order changed), or if they would provide additional context to the agent. In case of above hyperlink, translator could want to check the hyperlink target for reference or need to add text outside of hyperlink text.
Ideally a consistent approach to all inline codes should be used during the extraction.
Example can be found in outermost_inline_excluded.

section.title: Incomplete Extraction of Inline Codes
section.para:
Implementers might choose not to process inline codes at all during the extraction and use one of the following approaches:
Use CDATA blocks as content of <source> and <target> elements (cdata)
Escape native codes using XML entities (inline_codes_plain_text)
Such incomplete extraction leaves inline codes unprotected and increases risk of their corruption during the roundtrip, thus pushing the problem of inline code handling downstream.

Modifiers could perform secondary extraction and still take advantages of native representation and according to specification, Writers may preserve original CDATA sections and text can be converted into inline codes.
Merges have to accept XLIFF files with valid modifications, even though they may ignore the added codes.
It's considered an XML internationalization best practice to avoid CDATA in localizable content.

section.title: Representing Multiple Subsequent Codes
section.para: As original inline codes can occur in clusters, typically nested formatting, implementer could be tempted to merge them and represent them as a single inline element.

Such extraction could prevent desirable modification of the inline codes, affecting quality of the translation; taking advantage of fine grained code metadata; or the automated actions, e.g. validation.

There is, however, a potential benefit of reducing markup inside segment content, which can be useful when using CAT tool that cannot properly render the inline codes, reducing the visual clutter and making the translatable text more readable. This can be solved by proper choice of CAT tool or by requiring the tool vendors to support proper rendering.
Implementers should weight the pros and cons of both approaches and use the most suitable one.
Examples can be found in multiple_codes_represented_as_single

section.title: Target Content in Extracted XLIFF
section.para: This section focuses on reasons whether or not to populate the <target> element during the Extraction or Enriching and when to do so if at all.

Generally, one should omit the <target> element, unless there is an added value. or if the specification offers a better approach. Correct support of the state machine during the whole roundtrip helps the agents to handle and validate the files in the proper way.

When looking at the situation from the microservices point of view, the Extractor/Merger could be implemented as just that — single purpose extraction/merging service, which would delegate other operations, such as segmentation or enriching to other specialized services.

Output of such extractor would be a target language agnostic XLIFF file with source content only, possibly with additional modules/extensions which could not be generated after extraction, for example Size and Length Restriction Moduleor Format Style Module.

Unless the customer has a need to create target language specific instance of the extracted XLIFF file, e.g. by enriching with translation candidates, the original XLIFF file could be sent downstream as-is.

section.title: State Machine
section.para: The XLIFF specification contains attributes for managing a segment state machine. The attributes used are <state> and <subState>. The <subState> attribute can only be used as long as the <state> attribute is used. The <state> attribute is for high level interoperability. The <subState> attribute allows implementers to define private sub-state machines that can give more fine-grained sub-states based on their private workflow needs.

The <state> attribute defines just a high level four states state engine. The values are initial, translated, reviewed, final. Although this attribute is optional on the <segment> element, it is assumed as having the default value initial whenever not used explicitly. There are some important advantages to using the state machine explicitly. Importantly, <target> elements are optional in the initial state. So if you want to even enforce <target> existence in your deliverables you should be using at least the high level four states state engine provided by the attribute state. Setting the state attribute to translated or later does enforce <target> existence within segments.
